content: Funding will not save your company.It's tempting for founders to believe that $1M pre-seed will solve their startup's challenges.The truth is that raising capital only magnifies existing problems.Here's exactly how I've seen funding destroy startups instead of saving them:1. Broken product developmentYou believe: "Funding means we can hire engineers and accelerate our roadmap!"What happens: You don‚Äôt talk to customers (which you can do without funding), so you create features for misaligned customers who eventually leave. You end up with a product entirely built on what you THOUGHT customers wanted instead of what they would actually pay for.2. Wasteful marketing spendYou believe: "After we raise, we'll invest in advertising and rapidly grow our user base!"What happens: You burn through cash on paid acquisition, reaching irrelevant audiences because you never invested time in defining your target customer.3. Slow and inconsistent salesYou believe: "Funding lets us build a sales team and scale our sales organization!"What happens: You hire sales reps prematurely without mastering founder-led sales. Without a proven playbook, there's no repeatability, and those hires fail. Plus, you increased your burn with these hires, so now that 24 months of runway you had has shrunk to just 6 months.Here's what I've discovered through building Chezie:Venture capital must be treated as fuel for an existing flame, not the spark itself.- Found product-market fit and ready to scale? Raise money to build faster.- Figured out a way to get in front of customers? Raise money so you can do it more frequently and quickly.- Consistently closing deals and surpassed $1M in ARR? Raise money to hire an SDR who now has a playbook to follow.If you‚Äôre still navigating product development, go-to-market, or sales fundamentals (which is entirely normal, by the way), don‚Äôt raise money.Instead, invest the time to solve these first.Abandon the fantasy that venture capital will rescue you. Embrace constraints, put in the work, and then leverage capital as an accelerant.I'm adding one more example of how founders assume funding will save them in the comments!What's the biggest mistake you made (or saw someone make) after raising their first round? Drop it in the comments - your story might save another founder from making the same error.

content: The worst thing that happened to our fundraise?We grew to $100k ARR in 4 months.It sounds backwards, but that early traction quickly became our biggest liability.We were so proud of those numbers. All we wanted to do was talk about and show off our logos. Chegg! Ripple! Branch! $100k ARR!We completely ignored what VCs actually care about: potential for outsized outcomes.THE MISTAKEOur initial pitch went something like:"Our ERG management solution helps companies operate their ERGs better. We're already doing $100k ARR with customers like Chegg and Ripple. We're raising $750k pre-seed."VC response every single time: "That's impressive, but how will you scale to $100M with this?"We had no answer because we were too busy celebrating our early wins to think about the big picture.THE FIXSo, we flipped our entire approach to focus on how we get big, and *casually* drop our revenue numbers.Our new pitch:"We want to help enterprises connect their most under-utilized asset (employee resource groups) to their business goals, like building a product or generating sales. Oh, by the way, we're already doing $100k ARR."The reception from VCs was almost instant.I remember the second or third time I delivered this new pitch, I watched a VC literally look up from their phone mid-call. They went from half-listening to fully engaged.Same traction. Same customers. Completely different reaction.THE LESSONThere‚Äôs a lesson here for pre-seed founders raising their first rounds:it's (almost) always better to lead with vision and supplement with traction.VCs don't care that you hit $100k ARR.They care that you can hit $100M ARR.Your early traction just proves you can execute and hustle.Show them the massive company you're building first. Then show that you've already figured out how to get customers without their money.That's when they lean in.Early traction is great. But if it becomes the only story you tell, it'll kill your fundraise faster than having no traction at all.I got this advice from a founder who‚Äôs raised over $300M. content: If you're fundraising to solve your startup's problems, you've already lost.I learned this after 80+ rejections üëáüèæI spent months pitching VCs, convinced that funding would solve everything.86 rejections later (yes, I counted), I finally understood: I was trying to raise money to close the gap, when I needed to close the gap to raise money.Let me explain.Last week, a founder building a monetization platform for niche creators (think Patreon for X) asked for my advice. She‚Äôd built a solid product and was obsessed with features.But when I asked how she'd get both creators AND users on the platform, he went quiet."That's what the funding is for," he said.Wrong answer.She‚Äôll struggle to raise until she can walk into a room and say: "We've cracked distribution. Here are our first 10 users, and here's our path to 1,000."That gap between where you are and where investors need you to be? That's your fundraising gap.And if you're a first-time founder without Stanford or YC on your resume, you can't raise with gaps.Here are the 5 fundraising gaps that kill pre-seed rounds:1. Founder perception gapThe stuff you can't change overnight - Stanford pedigree, ex-Google, second-time founder status. If you don't have it, the other gaps become dealbreakers.2. Team gapCan you actually build this? Do you have the expertise? One technical co-founder isn't enough if you're building deep tech.3. Traction gapNot just users - PAYING customers or serious daily/monthly active users. "We'll monetize later" doesn't work in 2025.4. Distribution gapA repeatable way to get customers that isn't paid ads. VCs need to see that you can grow without burning their cash on Meta ads.5. Market gapProving the market is both big AND growing. A big stagnant market is just as bad as a small one.The truth is, if you have founder perception working for you, VCs will ignore the other gaps.If you don't (like 99% of us), you need to close these gaps BEFORE you fundraise.The marketplace founder? She needs to spend the next 3 months figuring out distribution, getting her first users, and showing momentum. Then she can raise.Stop fundraising, hoping someone will eventually say yes. Figure out your gaps. Close them. Then raise money to pour fuel on what's already working.What's the biggest gap between where you are today and where you need to be to fundraise?Drop it below - I read every comment and will share specific strategies ü§ùüèæ

Like comically small.Case study: Morgan Smith, founder of ElevoMorgan is a fractional HR consultant juggling multiple clients.Her problem: She's got too many tools.- Bill.com for invoicing- Toggle for time tracking- ClickUp for project management- + dozens moreHer idea: build the "Salesforce for solopreneurs" - an all-in-one platform handling everything solopreneurs need.This sounds good, but there‚Äôs one (big) problem.If you build a product for every use case for every customer, you'll do everything just okay.When it comes to building product, the rule of thumb is 10x better or don‚Äôt bother.Instead, start with ONE value prop for ONE type of customer that solves a very painful problem really well.I worked with Morgan to drill down to her personal biggest pain point: client management.Now, she‚Äôs pivoted to building elevo, a client management platform specifically for fractional talent.Here‚Äôs how to niche down like Morgan:1. List your customer types - Morgan had solopreneurs, fractionals, consultants, and contractors2. Pick the one you understand best - She IS a fractional consultant3. Build that one thing really well - Client management that actually works for how fractionals operatePaypal started as a payments platform solely for eBay sellers.Slack started as a messaging platform for software developers.The biggest companies started way smaller than you might think.If you're a first-time founder, start small and nail a problem for one specific customer type. For my pre-seed, I created a list of 30 target VCs. I quickly learned I needed to 10x that. Here's why first-time founders should identify 300+ funds to raise their first $1M ‚¨áÔ∏èBuilding your investor pipeline isn't about finding a handful of "perfect fit" funds.It's about understanding the (pretty low) conversion rates at each stage of the funnel.When I raised our pre-seed for Chezie, for every 10 investors on our target list, I got a meeting with only 3 of them - a 30% target-to-meeting conversion rate.For every 30 meetings, I got just 1 check. That‚Äôs a 3% meeting-to-check conversion rate.Here are some benchmarks for a first-time founder to use:- 50% list-to-response rate - For every 10 outreach attempts, only 5 investors will respond at all- 40% response-to-meeting rate - Of those who respond, only 4 out of 10 will agree to take a meeting- 5% meeting-to-check rate - Of those who take meetings, only 1 in 20 will actually write a checkMost people you reach out to won't respond.Of those who do respond, most will turn you down.And of those who actually meet with you, only 5% will write a check.If you're a first-time founder without YC backing or previous exits, don‚Äôt plan on better conversion rates than this.Now, let's reverse-engineer what this means for a $1M round.On average, to raise $1M, you‚Äôll need to secure 3 checks. The typical structure:- 1 lead check: $750k- 1 strong follow-on: $150k- 1 smaller follow-on: $100kLastly, let‚Äôs work backwards to figure out how many funds you need to add to your list:1. At 5% meeting-to-check odds, each investment requires 20 meetings2. 3 investments √ó 20 meetings = 60 total meetings needed3. At 40% response-to-meeting rate, each meeting requires 2.5 responses4. 60 meetings √ó 2.5 responses = 150 responses needed5. At 50% list-to-response rate, you need 300 investors on your target listThis sounds harsh, but it‚Äôs better to go in with realistic expectations than get burnt out after rejection #30.Fundraising success is about two things: 1. persistence, and 2. strategy.Knowing how many investors to identify is your foundation.A rule of thumb for any first-time founder raising their first $1M: start with 300 funds and go from there.Save this post and share with a founder friend!P.S. - I detailed this process in my CREAM eBook. We burned $5,000 (10% of our runway at the time) on a feature for a customer who never signed.¬†Best mistake we ever made.The customer seemed perfect:- They would be a big logo, especially for our first customer.- They loved our product.- They asked great questions.- They had budget allocated to buy.Then they hit us with: "We'd love to move forward, but we need Okta SSO integration first."I was ecstatic. This would be our first customer, and SSO is a reasonable request for an enterprise company.Instead of digging deeper, I immediately promised we could build it.6 weeks of back-and-forth. Weekly check-ins with their team. Constant updates on our progress building the integration."Great news! We have Okta SSO!"Then crickets.A few weeks later, the customer got back to us to let us know they were going a different direction.After hundreds of sales conversations, I know one thing for sure:Products are bought, not sold.When customers really want your product, they find reasons to buy it. When they don't, they find excuses not to.Most "if you build this, we'll sign" requests are just polite ways to say no.90% of these customers won't sign anyway. The other 10% will sign and make your life miserable with endless feature requests.Whenever I talk to a customer who requests a feature, I ask one question:"If we had [feature] today, would you sign the contract this week?"If yes, find a path forward (add it as a customization in the contract, extend the term by a few months to factor in the build, etc.).If no, call it out and move on.Luckily for us, 70% of our customers now use that Okta integration. So it wasn't a total loss.But I learned to stop chasing customers who are looking for reasons to say no.Funny enough, I‚Äôm 3.5 years into building Chezie, and I still find myself biting on feature requests from potential customers.The difference is that I now ask the hard questions first. content: The best fundraising advice I ever received came from a founder who's raised $353M:Raise on traction or vision, but never both.In a brief interaction with Christina Cacioppo of Vanta, she shared this nugget with me. Only 0.05% of startups founders successfully raise venture capital.That's 1 in every 10,000 founders.If you want to improve your odds, you have to prioritize your investors. Here‚Äôs how I did it to successfully close my pre-seed üëáüèæYou often hear that fundraising is like sales. While they aren‚Äôt 100% similar, a through line is that, like in sales, not every prospect is equal. Successful founders prioritize their target funds before they start raising. To make it simple, categorize investors by four categories: location, stage, sector, and (most importantly) whether or not you can get a warm intro.Then, prioritize with this framework:Low priority: Match on one criteria (location, stage, or sector)Medium priority: Match on 2-3 criteriaHigh priority: Match on all three + clear path to warm introA key point is that the status of a fund does NOT equal priority. For example, a notable fund like Andressen Horowitz is, on paper, a good fit for my company Chezie:- They invest in B2B SaaS ‚úì- They invest in pre-seed/seed stages ‚úì- They've backed other HR tech companies like ChartHop ‚úìBut I put them as medium priority because I didn‚Äôt have anyone who could introduce me. Sure, I could send a cold email, but since warm intros matter so much, not having one meant that prioritizing them would probably be a waste of time. Raising VC is about getting momentum. Prioritizing funds means that you save the best for last. This means that by the time you get to that perfect-fit, high-priority fund:1. You know your pitch forward and backward2. You have responses to every question that a VC is going to ask3. You *might* even have a commitment from another fund to create some real FOMO for that investorInvestors won‚Äôt say this but the best chance you have to get a check is the first meeting you have. Prioritize your funds so you‚Äôre pitching your top targets when you‚Äôre most ready. For other founders who‚Äôve raised, how did you go about prioritizing investors? When I started my company I got a crash course in product management. 3 years later, I can confidently say this is the biggest thing I‚Äôve learned:Be 10x better, or don‚Äôt bother. When building a startup, you're not just fighting other tools; you're fighting 'the way we've always done it.'Think about it:‚Ä¢ Users have existing processes‚Ä¢ Teams have muscle memory‚Ä¢ Change can mean retraining an entire organizationYou need to be dramatically better to take users away from their current process. Not a little bit better. Not twice as good.10x better.Here's an example from our latest feature Chezie:We're building a Slack integration that lets ERG leaders broadcast messages to their groups. We had two options:1. Ship a basic plain-text message builder quickly2. Build a full drag-and-drop Slack block kit builderThe easy path is option 1. But we asked ourselves:"If we just offer plain text, why would our users stop typing directly in Slack?"They wouldn't.So we're building a proper block kit builder that makes creating Slack messages as intuitive as building emails.Yes, it's taking longer.Yes, it's more complex.But it will be 10x better than simply sending messages directly in Slack. The takeaway is that in B2B software, changing tools means changing ingrained habits - not just for one person, but for entire teams.To make your buyers adopt your product you need to be 10x better than the existing process.

Founders who raise a pre-seed, seed, and series A end up owning less than 50% of their companies. There‚Äôs a way to build a big business and retain 80%+ ownership: the one-and-one round of funding. Here‚Äôs how it works üëáüèæA typical VC-backed company raises three rounds of funding by Series A:- Pre-seed: to validate the idea- Seed: to validate the GTM- Series A: to validate the marketThis usually looks like:‚Ä¢ Pre-seed ($300K at $3M post)‚Ä¢ Seed ($1M at $5M post)‚Ä¢ Series A ($5M+ at $20M post)By Series A, the founders have been diluted to own about 50% of their company.With the one-and-done route, founders can get to market validation and still own 80% of their company. Instead of raising a pre-seed, hustle to get the company off the ground:- Build with no-code tools instead of hiring a developer- Offer services to customers to get revenue- Consider keeping your day job so you don‚Äôt have to worry about paying yourselfIt might take a bit longer, but founders who follow this path should be able to grow to $100k+ ARR and have an idea of how they can get to $500k or $1M. Now, it‚Äôs time to raise the ONE round. Let‚Äôs assume it‚Äôs $1M on a $5M valuation. That‚Äôs 20% dilution. The founders are in the same spot as those who follow the traditional route, with one big difference:They own 80% of their company. With $1M in funding and a validated idea, these founders can hit the gas peddle.‚Ä¢ Double down on what's working‚Ä¢ Aim for 100-200% YoY growth‚Ä¢ Stay efficient with capital‚Ä¢ Build toward profitabilityWhen it‚Äôs time to raise a Series A, the founders have optionality.If you want to raise to grow faster, go for it. If you like the way things are going, then don‚Äôt raise. Here's why this matters:Traditional path = Always raising, heavily dilutedOptimal path = Control your destiny, keep your equityYour company doesn't need three rounds to succeed. It needs sustainable growth and founders who maintain control.- - - Thanks to Calvin Rupango for the inspiration for this post!

content: When we raised our pre-seed, I aimed to raise a $25k friends and family round.To our surprise, we got over $160k! Here‚Äôs how we did itüëáüèæEven if you don‚Äôt want to raise VC, every founder should raise a friends and family round. It‚Äôs an opportunity to create wealth for the people in your life that are cheering you on.How did we go about raising the round? Like everything else, it was a process:1. I contacted my friends and family to let them know that we were fundraising and to ask if they were interested. I made it clear that there was no pressure whatsoever. At this point, we‚Äôd been working on Chezie for about 2 years, so folks knew about the company.2. Next, we worked with our legal counsel (shoutout Mission Law) to open a roll-up vehicle (RUV) via AngelList. An RUV lets people invest via a debit card and sets up the round so it‚Äôs ONE line on your cap table.3. When we got interest, my co-founder Dumebi Egbuna and I scheduled an open pitch via Zoom. We treated it like a VC pitch. We showed people:- Problem/Solution- Financial projections- Competition- Go-to-market+ everything else that goes into a traditional pitchThere were about 20 people on that call. At the end, we opened the floor for Q&A. We shared the RUV link with everyone after the meeting.4. Over the next two months, I answered questions from those who were interested. I didn‚Äôt care that some people would invest just $1,000. This support was essential to me, and I felt responsible for ensuring they were comfortable investing.To our disbelief, there was over $150k in the RUV after two months.We had parents of friends invest their money on top of what their kids put in. A friend of mine invested, got a raise at her job, and then invested some more. I get emotional just thinking about it. The money from our friends and family plus what we raised from VCs and other investors carried us through our goal of $750k.Many underrepresented founders don‚Äôt bother trying to raise a friends and family because they don‚Äôt think their network will be willing/able to invest.My number one piece of advice is this:Let your friends and family decide that for themselves.The people who have supported you from day one deserve a chance to invest. content: Only 2.2% of VC funding went to women founders in 2024.Black founders? 0.48%. LGBTQ+ founders? 0.5%.If VCs actually want to improve these numbers (big if), here are 5 things they could start doing:1. Ban the warm introYou can't get warm intros without social capital. And underrepresented founders often lack the networks that make this possible. As long as access to capital requires social capital, diverse founders are going to take an L.2. Be direct with your "no"- "Let me know when you have a lead investor"- "You're too early for us"- "Keep us updated on your progress"These are all indirect ways of saying no. So instead of beating around the bush, just say you‚Äôre not interested so founders can pursue investors who are genuinely interested.3. Give real feedbackDon't say that the "metrics aren't there." Tell us which metrics matter and what benchmarks you're looking for. Specific feedback helps founders improve and better understand what investors want.4. Look beyond SF and NYCWhen you only invest in major tech hubs, you're saying you only want founders who can afford $4K/month rent. Remember: Mailchimp ($12B), Calendly ($3B), and Duo Security ($2.35B) weren't built in SF.5. Diversify LP basesIt makes sense that diverse LPs would lead to diverse founders. They bring different networks, understand overlooked markets, and can better evaluate opportunities in their communities.Will any of this happen? Probably not.These changes would mean disrupting systems that work really well for VCs and their existing networks. It would cost them traditional deal flow and require more work.But maybe in 2025, we'll see some brave firms try something different.Until then, we‚Äôll keep building, growing, and finding ways to succeed despite the barriers.Founders: What other changes could help improve funding access for underrepresented founders?
